title: Section 101 — Murder (definition)
text_summary: Defines murder as culpable homicide with specific intent/knowledge thresholds; recognizes exceptions where culpable homicide is not murder.
ingredients: intention to cause death OR intention to cause such bodily injury as is likely to cause death OR knowledge that act is so imminently dangerous that it must in all probability cause death
exceptions: private defence exceeding power without premeditation
act of public servant without ill‑will (limited)
illustrations: A stabs B in the heart intending to cause death — murder.
A causes bodily injury known to be likely to cause death — murder.
exam_notes: Know difference between culpable homicide and murder tests; map from IPC s.300 to BNS s.101.
chunk_text: BNS s.101 defines when culpable homicide amounts to murder based on intention/knowledge, subject to specified exceptions.

title: Section 103 — Punishment for murder
text_summary: Whoever commits murder is punishable with death or life imprisonment and fine; enhanced minimum in certain group‑based murders.
punishment: Death or life imprisonment and fine; in specified group‑based murders, not less than 7 years up to life or death and fine.
exam_notes: Remember aggravated clause for group of ≥5 acting on prohibited grounds.
chunk_text: Punishment provision for murder including aggravated scenarios where a group of five or more commits murder on specified discriminatory grounds.

title: Section 173 — Information in cognizable cases (FIR, incl. Zero FIR, e‑FIR)
chapter: Information to the Police and their powers to investigate
text_summary: Every information of a cognizable offence may be given orally or by electronic communication; must be recorded and a free copy given. Provision for preliminary enquiry in certain 3–<7 year offences; Zero FIR allowed irrespective of jurisdiction.
ingredients: recording and signature within 3 days if electronic
illustrations: Woman complainant in sexual offences: to be recorded by woman officer; video‑recording and magistrate statement as applicable.
exam_notes: Compare CrPC s.154 → BNSS s.173; remember preliminary enquiry window for 3–<7 year offences with DSP permission.
chunk_text: BNSS s.173 governs how cognizable‑offence information is recorded, including e‑FIR, Zero FIR and preliminary enquiry parameters.

title: Section 175 — Police officer’s power to investigate cognizable case; magistrate‑directed investigation
text_summary: Officer in charge may investigate any cognizable case without Magistrate’s order; SP/DySP oversight possible. Magistrate may order investigation on complaint in specified scenarios.
ingredients: officer in charge of police station
exam_notes: Map to old CrPC s.156. Link with remedy when FIR not registered.
chunk_text: BNSS s.175 preserves police power to investigate cognizable cases and enables Magistrate‑directed investigation in certain circumstances.

title: Sections 62–63 — Electronic records: proof and admissibility
text_summary: Electronic/digital records may be primary evidence; admissible if Section 63 conditions satisfied. Certificate requirements updated for electronic outputs.
exceptions: primary electronic original may not require certificate similar to IEA 65B jurisprudence; verify per BSA text
illustrations: Server logs/CCTV printouts tendered with requisite certification.

leading_cases.name: Arjun Panditrao Khotkar v. Kailash Kushanrao Gorantyal
leading_cases.ratio: Certificate requirement for secondary electronic evidence emphasised under IEA; compare with BSA changes.

exam_notes: Know what counts as primary vs secondary electronic evidence post‑BSA; cite s.62–63 language.
chunk_text: BSA recognises electronic/digital records as evidence. Section 63 sets conditions for admissibility of computer outputs and electronic records.

title: Dangerous driving — offence & penalty (post‑2019 amendments)
text_summary: Driving in a manner dangerous to the public is punishable; 2019 amendments enhanced fines and imprisonment thresholds. State compounding may apply.
ingredients: nature, condition and use of the place
punishment: Enhanced fines and imprisonment as amended in 2019; verify current state notifications for compounding amounts.
illustrations: Speeding zig‑zag through dense traffic endangering others.
exam_notes: Remember interaction with CMVR for standards; check state challan tables.
chunk_text: MVA s.184 sets the offence of dangerous driving; penalties increased by the 2019 Amendment Act; state compounding schedules vary.
